CIPROFLOXACIN

QUINOLONES

  • Pregnancy
  • Renal impairment
  • Side effects
  • Patient and carer advice
  • Cautions
  • Unlicensed use
  • Prescribing and dispensing
  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

Superficial bacterial eye infection,

To the eye using eye ointment

  • For adults
    Apply 4 times a day for maximum duration of treatment 21 days.
  • For adults
    Apply 1.25 centimetres 3 times a day for 2 days, then apply 1.25 centimetres twice daily for 5 days.
  • For children
    Apply 4 times a day for maximum duration of treatment 21 days.
  • For children 1–17 years
    Apply 1.25 centimetres 3 times a day for 2 days, then apply 1.25 centimetres twice daily for 5 days.

Superficial bacterial eye infection (severe infection),

To the eye using eye drop

  • For adults
    Apply every 2 hours during waking hours for 2 days, then apply 4 times a day for maximum duration of treatment 21 days.
  • For children
    Apply every 2 hours during waking hours for 2 days, then apply 4 times a day for maximum duration of treatment 21 days.

Corneal ulcer,

To the eye using eye ointment

  • For adults
    Apply every 15 minutes for 6 hours, then apply every 30 minutes for the remainder of day 1, then apply every 1 hour on day 2, then apply every 4 hours on days 3–14, maximum duration of treatment 21 days, to be administered throughout the day and night.
  • For adults
    Apply 1.25 centimetres every 1–2 hours for 2 days, then apply 1.25 centimetres every 4 hours for the next 12 days, to be administered throughout the day and night.
  • For children
    Apply every 15 minutes for 6 hours, then apply every 30 minutes for the remainder of day 1, then apply every 1 hour on day 2, then apply every 4 hours on days 3–14, maximum duration of treatment 21 days, to be administered throughout the day and night.
  • For children 1–17 years
    Apply 1.25 centimetres every 1–2 hours for 2 days, then apply 1.25 centimetres every 4 hours for the next 12 days, to be administered throughout the day and night.

Fistulating Crohn's disease,

By mouth

  • For adults
    500 mg twice daily.

Respiratory-tract infections,

By intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    500–750 mg twice daily.
  • For adults
    400 mg every 8–12 hours, to be given over 60 minutes.

Pseudomonal lower respiratory-tract infection in cystic fibrosis,

By mouth

  • For adults
    750 mg twice daily.

Urinary-tract infections,

By intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    250–750 mg twice daily.
  • For adults
    400 mg every 8–12 hours, to be given over 60 minutes.

Acute uncomplicated cystitis in women,

By mouth

  • For adults
    250 mg twice daily for 3 days.

Acute or chronic prostatitis,

By intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    500 mg twice daily for 28 days.
  • For adults
    400 mg every 8–12 hours, to be given over 60 minutes.

Gonorrhoea,

By mouth

  • For adults
    500 mg for 1 dose.

Most other infections,

By intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    Initially 500 mg twice daily; increased to 750 mg twice daily, in severe or deep-seated infection.
  • For adults
    400 mg every 8–12 hours, to be given over 60 minutes.

Surgical prophylaxis,

By mouth

  • For adults
    750 mg, to be taken 60 minutes before procedure.

Anthrax (treatment and post-exposure prophylaxis),

By intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    500 mg twice daily.
  • For adults
    400 mg every 12 hours, to be given over 60 minutes.

Prevention of secondary case of meningococcal meningitis,

By mouth

  • For adults
    500 mg for 1 dose.
  • For children 1 month–4 years
    30 mg/kg (max. per dose 125 mg) for 1 dose.
  • For children 5–11 years
    250 mg for 1 dose.
  • For children 12–17 years
    500 mg for 1 dose.

Advice when patient is pregnant

With intravenous use or oral use

A single dose of ciprofloxacin may be used for the prevention of a secondary case of meningococcal meningitis.

When used by eye

Manufacturer advises use only if potential benefit outweighs risk.

Advice regarding renal impairment

With oral use in adults

Give 250–500 mg every 12 hours if eGFR 30–60 mL/minute/1.73 m2 (every 24 hours if eGFR less than 30 mL/minute/1.73 m2).

With intravenous use in adults

Give (200 mg over 30 minutes), 200–400 mg every 12 hours if eGFR 30–60 mL/minute/ 1.73m2 (every 24 hours if eGFR less than 30 mL/ minute/1.73 m2).

With intravenous use or oral use in children

Reduce dose if estimated glomerular filtration rate less than 30 mL/minute/1.73 m2—consult product literature.

Known side effects

Specific side effects

commonOrVeryCommon: corneal deposits (reversible after completion of treatment), ocular discomfort, ocular hyperaemia, taste disturbance, flatulence, pain at injection site, phlebitis at injection site, flatulence,

uncommon: increased lacrimation, blurred vision, conjunctival hyperaemia, corneal infiltrates, corneal staining, eye dryness, eye irritation, eye pain, eye pruritus, eye swelling, eyelid disorders, eyelid erythema, eyelid exfoliation, eyelid oedema, headache, keratopathy, nausea, photophobia,

rare: abdominal pain, asthenopia, corneal disorders, corneal epithelium defect, dermatitis, diarrhoea, diplopia, dizziness, ear pain, eye hypoaesthesia, keratitis, paranasal sinus hypersecretion, rhinitis, abnormal dreams, chest pain, dysphagia, dyspnoea, erythema nodosum, hot flushes, hyperglycaemia, hypoglycaemia, oedema, pancreatitis, sweating, syncope, tachycardia, abnormal dreams, chest pain, dysphagia, dyspnoea, erythema nodosum, hot flushes, hyperglycaemia, hypoglycaemia, oedema, pancreatitis, sweating, syncope, tachycardia,

veryRare: intracranial hypertension, movement disorders, tenosynovitis, tinnitus, vasculitis in children, intracranial hypertension, movement disorders, tenosynovitis, tinnitus, vasculitis in children,

notKnown: peripheral neuropathy, polyneuropathy, peripheral neuropathy, polyneuropathy,

Advice for patients and carers

In children

Medicines for Children leaflet: Ciprofloxacin ear drops for ear infections

www.medicinesforchildren.org.uk/ciprofloxacin-ear-drops-ear-infections-0

In children

Medicines for Children leaflet: Ciprofloxacin for bacterial infections

www.medicinesforchildren.org.uk/ciprofloxacin-bacterial-infections-0

Cautions regarding administration

  • With intravenous use: acute myocardial infarction (risk factor for QT interval prolongation)
  • With intravenous use: avoid excessive alkalinity of urine (risk of crystalluria)
  • With intravenous use: bradycardia (risk factor for QT interval prolongation)
  • With intravenous use: congenital long QT syndrome (risk factor for QT interval prolongation)
  • With intravenous use: electrolyte disturbances (risk factor for QT interval prolongation)
  • With intravenous use: ensure adequate fluid intake (risk of crystalluria)
  • With intravenous use: heart failure with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (risk factor for QT interval prolongation)
  • With intravenous use: history of symptomatic arrhythmias (risk factor for QT interval prolongation)
  • With oral use: acute myocardial infarction (risk factor for QT interval prolongation)
  • With oral use: avoid excessive alkalinity of urine (risk of crystalluria)
  • With oral use: bradycardia (risk factor for QT interval prolongation)
  • With oral use: congenital long QT syndrome (risk factor for QT interval prolongation)
  • With oral use: electrolyte disturbances (risk factor for QT interval prolongation)
  • With oral use: ensure adequate fluid intake (risk of crystalluria)
  • With oral use: heart failure with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (risk factor for QT interval prolongation)
  • With oral use: history of symptomatic arrhythmias (risk factor for QT interval prolongation)

Unlicensed use

When used by eye in children

Eye ointment not licensed for use in children under 1 year.

With intravenous use or oral use in children

Not licensed for use in children under 1 year of age.

Licensed for use in children over 1 year for complicated urinary-tract infections, for pseudomonal lower respiratory-tract infections in cystic fibrosis, for prophylaxis and treatment of inhalational anthrax. Licensed for use in children over 1 year for other infections where the benefit is considered to outweigh the potential risks.

Not licensed for use in children for gastro-intestinal anthrax.

Not licensed for use in children for prophylaxis of meningococcal meningitis.

Information regarding prescribing and dispensing

Flavours of oral liquid formulations may include strawberry.

Prepared medicinal forms of CIPROFLOXACIN

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: eye drops, oral suspension, ear drops,
Tablet
Oral suspension
Infusion
Solution for infusion
Eye drops
Eye ointment
